text: I absolutely loved this book. I wont lie, it does take about the first 30 or so pages to get into it, and I was also a little confused because there are really two stories going on that connect everything in the end, but once I figured out what was what, I loved it! I relly liked the characters also. There were so many qualities to love about Taylor and her friends in this story. While I read the ARC, Im sure anyone who picks up the published edition will love this story too. It has a lot about family, friendship, love, growing up, letting go and holding on-at the same time, sadness and joy with a lot of laughs in between. Also, I love that there is a little bit of mystery to it!

I stand corrected. This one was wonderful once I got through it. Now I need to go back and read the whole thing again now that I know how it's all tied together. Marchetta still rocks! I'm not sure how many teens will get through this, but I have a newfound respect for the Printz committee. :-)OK - I'm trying this one again - moving it back up from my "Could Not Finish" list. A friend who helped select it for the Printz award said that the ARC had tons of errors. So now I have the real thing. We'll see if it's any better this time around....Oh man - I LOVED Marchetta's "Saving Francesca", so when I saw her newest at ALA I grabbed the ARC. But I'm so disappointed to say that I couldn't get through it... It's a very odd story about Taylor, a girl who lives at a boarding school since being abandoned by her mother at age 11. Each fall, the students at the school engage in a "war" with the townies and a group of cadets that come to camp in the woods near the school. Each team has their own territory, and there are constant skirmishes between the groups. Taylor is appointed the leader of her group, so the book is divided into a plotline about the battle, but interspersed with stuff about Taylor's past life and the mystery behind her mom's disappearance. It's very confusing. Lots of typos in the ARC too, which made it even harder to read. I tried for 100 pages, but had other better stuff calling me. Oh well.
As others have said, this one was a bit slow-going and confusing at first, but once it all started coming together it was an affecting story.

While the beginning is a bit confusing, it's well worth pushing through until things start to become clear - for the reader and for Taylor. It's only appropriate, really, for the beginning to confuse us, since Taylor is sort of lost herself. Since she is telling us the story as she struggles with her role at school, her missing mother, the disappearance of a favorite adult, and needy peers, we see her frustrated state of mind. There are intriguing hints of a story that took place a generation before, and slowly the two stories connect. The ending is an unexpectedly forceful tearjerker, with happy and painful moments crushed together. At its heart, it feels like a story about how character and friendships can be formed at an early age, and how those moments never really leave a person - but it never turns the story into anything cheesy. I do think that this focus will appeal to teens who are in that intense friendship stage. This begs to be reread.Recommended to readers looking for an emotionally gripping story who have the patience for a slow start. There's some violence - car accidents, fights, a suicide, hints of child abuse - that are more emotionally intense than graphic, as are the brief sex scenes. Updated: she's won the Printz! Hallelujah, it gives me an excuse to reread it right away.

For the first half of this book, I could not figure out what all the hype was about. I couldn't keep all the characters placed, I couldn't figure out why in the world these boarding school kids were having some kind of war, and couldn't figure out what the hell Taylor's attitude problem was all about. Then, I hit the halfway point. And I couldn't put it down. This book is about love and friendship and families. It's about facing tough situations and realizing that sometimes there's more to your history then the things you can remember. It's a relationship book--about characters more than action or a particular plot. And it is lovely. I really liked it a lot.

Although I had a very hard time getting into this story, I found that it was so worth the effort once all the fragments of people and circumstances started weaving together. The story is like a puzzle, and all the more engaging for it. Now that I've finished, I have to go back to the beginning and pick up pieces I missed throughout the beginning before I knew who everyone would become later. If this doesn't make any sense, READ THE STORY.......you'll be glad you tried it!

I just finished reading this book, and WOW! First off, I feel compelled to admit that for the first half of the book, I didn't really care for it. I was confused by the different story lines and couldn't shake the feeling that I was supposed to know more about things than I did. If anyone else is reading the book and feels that way - STICK WITH IT! It all becomes crystal clear - even the cat has a purpose and a part in the story. I wish I had time to read it again right away. It's beautiful.
A bit melodramatic, but still very touching.

About a dozen swear words (the f word a couple times). There is teenage sex, but very briefly and not in great detail.This book has a slow start. There are two plots from two time periods and two groups of friends, that, by the end all fit together. But until pieces start to click into place in your mind, it's completely confusing.

What I learned from this book is that it is a huge payoff novel. That means it all comes together at the end in a huge way. Which is great because I found the beginning hard to get into, but I had the feeling (plus a friend told me) that it was totally worth sticking with it. And it was. It's also a book that begs to be reread, and if I had the time, I would totally do that just to catch all of the nuance and stuff I missed the first time.

Taylor’s mother drove hundreds of miles to abandon Taylor on the Jellicoe Road when she was 11. Now 17, Taylor is the reluctant leader of the students at the Jellicoe School in a territory war against the Townies and the Cadets. If she didn’t already have enough on her plate, Hannah, who is the closest thing Taylor has to family, has disappeared, leaving only a story she wrote about five kids who lived on the Jellicoe Road 18 years ago. Where did Hannah go? Why does the aloof Jonah Griggs, leader of the Cadets, seem to know Taylor better than she knows herself? Who is the mysteriousboy who sits out on a tree every night in Taylor’s dreams? What about the Hermit who once whispered something in Taylor’s ear? As pieces of the puzzle reveal themselves., it soon becomes clear that there is a connection between Taylor’s mysterious past and Hannah’s story.2009 Michael L. Printz Award Winner.

This book (current Printz award winner) is not technically a mystery, except for the mystery of Taylor's past, which is slowly revealed throughout the book. It takes place in Australia, at a school on the Jellicoe Road, where Taylor is a senior and head of house at the Jellicoe School. The first 6 weeks of the school year, when the Cadets are training nearby, there are territory "wars" between the Houses, the Cadets, and the Townies. There's a lot of tension in this story between the characters as well as Taylor's mysterious past from before the time her mother left her at a Seven-Eleven on the Jellicoe Road when she was 10. It kept me reading, and had a satisfying ending.

I will freely admit that I didn’t really get hooked on this book until I was over a hundred pages in. In fact, this is a book I have picked up and started several times before and ended up putting it down. I think the only way I got through it this time is because I made a commitment to read it, and I am so glad I did. Jellicoe Road is a story about tragedy and triumph, family and friends, hope and loss. It tells the story of two families, the Markham’s and the Schroeder’s, and their lives on the Jellicoe Road. Our primary narrator for the novel is Taylor Markham, who was abandoned by her mother at a 7-eleven on Jellicoe Road when she was 11 years old. As Taylor reluctantly accepts a leadership role at her school and leads the war against the townies and cadets, she also starts down a path of self discovery, where she discovers her own history and who she really is.Nothing in this novel is as it seems and it takes quite a while for the pieces of the puzzle to begin to fall into place. Once you get to that part, though, it becomes nearly impossible to put the book down. Highly recommended.Cautions for sensitive readers: There is some profanity in the book and some sexual situations. There is also a violent car accident that is referred to with some graphic depictions.

Wow, this book was amazing. I'd give it a nine out of ten because I don't think it would really appeal to EVERYONE and the beginning is a bit slow, but I thought it was just a terrific book. I loved watching the pieces click together, and I liked all the character - flawed but lovable. This is the best Printz book I've read; even beats out Looking for Alaska for me.
Still not sure about the Printz award, but in the end I did like it. The multigenerational nature of the story and the complexity of how the plot ties together both make this one worth reading.

In some ways this book is brilliant and amazing, and I’m tempted to give it 5 stars, but for enjoyment value and overall, it was a solid 4 star book for me.I love orphan stories and boarding school stories and this story fit the bill.I’ve rarely read a book where felt so confused by what is going on while simultaneously enjoying it. It took a good ¼ to 1/3 the book to basically get what was going on and much further on to get all my questions answered, yet reading it was a satisfying and fun experience; I was more intrigued than frustrated as I read and tried to fathom what was going on.I do think it screams out for a reread, and because I’m committed to reading other books and knew I wouldn’t be rereading this book in the near future, about ¾ the way through I went back and skimmed/read all the passages in italics in order to to bring myself up to speed. I think reading it for a second time would be even more enjoyable, but I did love most of it.There is a completely engaging writing style and memorable, complicated characters, both very satisfying!Some things I liked best: The parts about To Kill a Mockingbird were great; Mrs. Dubose was a character that always made a huge impression on me. The humor comes at opportune times in this story, in many places; I thought page 300 was particularly hilarious, and all the humor was so welcome because this story has components that are sad, tragic, scary, and otherwise dark.Some things I liked least: The dream sequences (except for one at the end that I did love, especially the way it solved one of the mysteries) and the allusions to life beyond death were not, for the most part, my cup of tea. And, maybe just a bit too much happened; I liked it all as I was reading it, but when I got to the end, I don’t know how to explain it, but it felt too busy. Given how much pleasure I got from reading it, perhaps I’m wrong and perhaps just the right amount of content was included. The seemingly mandatory teen romance(s) that are in young adult books with teenage characters; I’d like to read just a few sans that plot point.It’s definitely worth continuing to read as the reader is eventually let in on everything that’s going on and all the mysteries are solved.4 to 4 ½ stars

For the first half of this book, I kept wondering how this book won the Printz award. But once the second half started, I could not put this book down and it all started to make sense. I really enjoyed it. At some point, I will have to re-read it.

I think that if I hadn't enjoyed Saving Francesca so much and if this book hadn't won the Printz, I would have put Jellicoe Road down around page 100. In those first hundred pages I had about zero understanding of what was going on, who these people were, or why I should care. But I kept reading and all of that worked itself out.Marchetta is a gifted writer, and she tends to work this slow burn thing to perfection. So if you pick this up please work up the patience to just keep going. Its worth it in the end.

I reviewed this late in 2008 for School Library Journal and found it complex, rich, and ultimately rewarding, but I am still surprised that it won the Printz Award. I would love some good reads types to read it and let me know what they think."School Library Journal (December 1, 2008)Gr 8 Up-For years, three factions-Townies, Cadets (city kids doing a six-week outdoor education program), and Jellicoe School students-have engaged in teen war games in the Australian countryside, defending territorial borders, negotiating for assets, and even taking hostages. Taylor Markham, a 17-year-old who was abandoned years ago by her mother, takes on leadership of the boarding school's six Houses. Plagued with doubts about being boss, she's not sure she can handle her Cadet counterpart, Jonah Griggs, whom she met several years before while running away to find her mother. When Hannah, a sort of house mother who has taken Taylor under her wing, disappears, Taylor puzzles over the book manuscript the woman left behind. Hannah's tale involves a tragic car accident on the Jellicoe Road more than 20 years earlier. Only three children survived, and Taylor discovers that this trio, plus a Cadet and a Townie, developed an epic friendship that was the foundation of the many mysteries in her life and identity, as well as of the war games. While the novel might put off casual readers, patient, thoughtful teens will remain to extract clues from the interwoven scraps of Hannah's narrative, just as Taylor does, all the while seeing the collapse of the barriers erected among the three groups over the years. Elegiac passages and a complex structure create a somewhat dense, melancholic narrative with elements of romance, mystery, and realistic fiction.-Suzanne Gordon, Peachtree Ridge High School, Suwanee, GA Copyright 2008 Reed Business Information."
Okay so this book started out a little confusing and jumbled, but once I figured out what was going on, I couldn't put it down. I actually had it in the car and was reading at red lights!

This was a really different book, but after I read it I realized how much more interesting it was to me then a lot of teen books. There's a lot of subplots that take place within the main story, but I think that it would be a great book to discuss and I'm glad it was chosen as the Printz winner this year. Part mystery, part romance, some action (territory wars)...I think a book a lot of teens would enjoy.

Marchetta's writing is better than ever in this book that's confusing at first, then beautiful and brilliantly written. It's about family, friendship, hope and despair, not to mention enduring love. I wish all Twilight fans could read Jellicoe Road to discover how authentic romance is written.

This was a fabulous book. The reason why it didn't get 5 stars was that the first part of the story was a bit confusing. It was a bit liked you jumped into the middle of a story and then had to scramble about to figure out what was going on. However, by mid book, I was gripped. I would recommend this book to anyone.

I spent the first half of the book thinking to myself, why in the world did this win the Prinz? I felt like the story was plodding along much too slowly and I was confused about what was going on. Then all of a sudden everything came together and I couldn't put it down. From reading other people's reviews, I see that I'm not the only one who felt this way. In the end I really enjoyed Jellicoe Road and I see why it won. I'm torn however about that first half though. I want to think that it is an artful and deliberate slow buildup but I'm not really sure.

Printz Award, huh? Hmm. The mystery surrounding Taylor's past is gripping, and the personal connections between the characters are deep and raw--the best part of the book. Marchetta spends too much time on the Townies-Cadets-Houses boundaries war in the beginning; I thought it was a "crazy adventures at boarding school" book for a while. Throughout the novel, I didn't have a vivid sense of place, either. Again, both generations of characters will stick with me, but the actual events of the narrative are fast leaving my head. The writing is good, not outstanding... I think both _Octavian II_ and _Tender Morsels_, Printz Honor Books for this year, were better.
This started slow, but was absolutely engrossing by the end.

Ok, so I finally understood what was going on in this book and then I really began to love it. I've never read anything by Marchetta but I think I will now because she writes beautifully. I can't give this 5 stars only b/c it took me so long to figure out and I think that people could really get lost and not finish the book. I only did because I knew it won the Printz and I wanted to see why, and I'm glad I stuck it out. This is one of those stories that stick with you.

Printz winner. I have many issues with this book: the "war" was poorly poorly done - sort of a plot driving after-thought. It exists but we won't really do anything with it. Almost all the adults in this book are totally irresponsible. I do not believe for one instant that two of the adult figures would have kept Taylor so far at arms (or longer) length. That the school is set up as it is with so few authority figures or people in charge is bogus. And the daily responsibilities of these teens are somehow not even a little in the way of the other things going on in their lives. That said. The plotting and the structure of this book are so interesting. Looking at other reviews, most readers complain that the first 100 pages are confusing (I agree). I don't think that was an accident. It is amusing to me that so many readers are so put off by that. The romance unfolds nicely and not necessarily predictably (and the 1st time paragraph might just be the best and most honest YA handling of a touchy topic). It is a great story and I liked it all the more for not being perfect.

Slow to start... just dumps you into the story mid-way and it took me awhile to figure out what exactly was happening, but once I did I really enjoyed the story. Very sweet scene depicting a 'first time'...

I read this because it got good reviews and , by the way, won the Printz award. I didn't like it at all at first because it was too confusing. I couldn't get a handle on anything. But I finally got into it and at the end I opened back to the beginning and re-read the whole thing (quicker this time) and liked it a lot. I don't think you should have to read a book 2x to get it, so I don't it deserves the Printz, but...I did like it the 2nd time around. Taylor lives at a school on Jellicoe Road. She was left in Jellicoe by her mother at age 11. 22 years earlier, there was a horrible accident on the Jellicoe Road. How the accident and Taylor's life merge is the basis of the story.

This year's Printz Award winner...if I hadn't been determined to read it, I'm not sure I would have made it past the first 50 pages. I was completely confused with the flashbacks and strange border wars. About half way through I started to get a feel for the characters and what they were actually doing, and the last 100 pages, I actually started liking the book. It took some work though.

Loved it, but still think others *start cough papertowns end cough* were better Printz contenders. This book didn't really catch me until the middle, where it grabbed me and made me sob. I loved pretty much all the characters, which is a big accomplishment.

I got on the library waitlist for this book because Amy kept saying it was amazing. The first fifty pages or so I really wasn't into it -- didn't like the main character, didn't really like the setup -- but I kept going because Amy had insisted.And I started to get into it, and the story became about so much more than the initial setup indicated, and the characters grew, and connections were made (narratively and relationally), and parts made me cry (in an "emotionally moving" way).I feel like a lot of the intensity [am being vague for spoiler-free-ness:] would seem melodramatic to a lot of readers, but it really works for me (which surprises me a smidgen -- though it probably shouldn't).

I'm torn about the rating I want to give this book. If I was judging just on the 1st 150 pages or so, I would give it a 2. I didn't feel engaged by the characters or by the turf war and quite frankly, if this hadn't been a Printz award winner, I don't know if I would have had the drive to finish it. However, the last 200-ish pages are a 4.5 or 5 for me. I liked the way the characters' stories all mesh together and I like the journey that Taylor ends up taking.

If I'd been reading this, instead of listening to it in 30-minute increments on the walk to and from work, I think I would have been racing through the last several chapters. It just gets better and better, connections building on connections, pieces clicking into place. I really loved that about it—it has all the charm of Saving Francesca, and then goes further—smarter, deeper, more intricate. The narration absolutely added to the experience—Rebecca Macauley does a brilliant job with all the characters, especially the teen girls and boys. I was fully engaged—I laughed, I gasped, I ate up the Aussie accents.A great, different coming-of-age story.

The story started slow. I didn't really get into it until page 200, but then I just couldn't put it down. As the story progressed I started to appreciate the first half of the book that I didn't really like because I realized I missed so much foreshadowing it was ridiculous. I completely understand why it won the Printz, but I liked Disreputable History better.It was a fun read that made me think. I love that combination.

The dual narrative of the story takes a while to understand. The plot is somewhat confusing and the cast of characters and their relationship to one another is not clear at first. The writing is beautiful and the sense of place outstanding. Taylor Markham is a strong female teen character. Fans of John Marsden and the Tomorrow Series will enjoy this book.

Like everyone else has said you have to get through like page 200 to really understand what is going on. The writing is amazing, she sucks you in and you can't stop reading. The characters are so lovely and I just couldn't help but tear up at the end. Such a captivating read.

My first go at reading Jellicoe Road was slow and wrought with confusion. I really wanted to get absorbed by the story because so many of my YA librarian colleagues were in love with the book, but I only made it through about 100 pages before it was due back to the library. A few months later, I decided to give it another chance and I’m glad I did. This time I was enchanted by Taylor Markham and the almost magical outback world she inhabits. Marchetta has beautifully interwoven the scattered stories of Narnie, et al. with Taylor’s present, creating a subtle, but increasingly urgent, mystery for both Taylor and the reader. Clues dropped earlier in the novel don’t become apparent until the end when all the dialogue, memories, and interactions of the characters come together. In Jellicoe and its environs, she has created a tremendous sense of place that grounds the story and becomes its own character of sorts. The territory wars between the students, the townies, and the cadets reinforce the importance of place in the book. I did find it cumbersome at first to keep track of all the characters and their relationships, especially the kids in Hannah’s story, but it all becomes clear in the end. Overall, Marchetta crafted a timeless, enjoyable, and extremely captivating novel.

This book took awhile to get into. At first I was confused by the cast of characters, but eventually figured them out. There seems to be several stories within stories going on in it that eventually interweave into each other. Once I got into it I enjoyed it, but it took awhile.
The disjointed threads all weave together in the end.

A book about growing up without parents, about friendships and relationships and loss and grieving. It has car crashes, "war" between cadets, townies and students, mysterious boys in trees, and other intriguing details. It took me a while to get into it, because there are a lot of characters to keep track of, both in present day and in a novel manuscript that the main character is reading. So you might want to have a scorecard handy. But it's totally worth it, as the characters start to intertwine and the levels of story get deeper. There are a lot of twists and surprises, and plenty of emotion. A really unique book. Winner of the Printz Award 2009.

I can definitely see why this was the Printz Award winner for 2009! It was one of the most original novels I've ever read. I think young women will especially like it. It deals with hard hitting issues like drug abuse, abandonment, self-hatred, and the pains of growing up in a difficult situation but also a little romance and love are thrown in to make it less heavy. At times it was confusing and hard to follow, but I'm sooooo glad I stuck with it. Bravo to Melina Marchetta!

I don't think I'll be re-reading annually like I do with Saving Francesca--but I really enjoyed this. I may even love it...but I'm not ready to commit...I have to read it a few more times. It has everything you've come to expect (and love!) from Melina Marchetta--but it's probably the most complex of her novels to date. The beginning is very jarring and hard to sink into, but if you stick with it (and re-read the first few pages a few times) the end result is well-worth the initial difficulty. I highly recommend!

Taylor Markham was abandoned by her mom when she was 11 and raised in an Australian boarding school by den mother Hannah. When Hannah mysteriously disappears one day, the search for her leads Taylor to discover things about herself (past, present and future) and those that love her.Marchetta's latest work is well done, but I didn't fall in love with it like the Printz committee. I found the plot to be too neat, a bit melodramatic and I didn't like how everything wrapped up a little too well. But the character development (particularly Taylor and Jonah) and the dialogue is great.Interestingly, I think the Printz committee must have taken teen appeal into consideration when they picked this book. I think teens will love the drama and how the puzzle fits together. It's definitely one I would recommend to teens.

Overall I really liked this book but I have to say it took at least 100 pages to really get what was going on and then the middle dragged on with all the "territory war" stuff...so I skipped a lot in the middle. But I LOVED the end and thus went back and read a lot that I had skipped.

I think this book would appeal to many teens because the central issues of the novel are timeless and cross cultural and racial barriers. I know that many people have been turned off by the confusion of the first few chapters, but I disagree, I think with the proper preparation, teens could really enjoy this book a lot. The book deals with the following developmental markers: surviving on your own/becoming independent, reconciling with your past, developing positive adult relationships, forgiveness, and understanding. I thought that the characters were believable. Taylor really appealed to me and drew me into the story. I wanted her to do well and succeed. I also liked the relationships amongst the characters; I thought they were realistic and believable. I was a bit doubtful that there would really be “territory wars” as described in the book, but upon understanding the history behind their creation, I can see how that would really happen too. In a sense, Taylor’s experiences could be a representation for the types of conflict that occur on a much larger scale around the world. I would promote this book in conjunction with other similarly themed novels: The Outsiders, Miracle’s Boys, or Westside Story, etc. I think that describing the basic plot and the way in which Marchetta has established the plot structure would be enough to entice a reader to want to pick the book up. I certainly enjoyed the novel, and I’m sure many others would too. 4Q, 4P, J/S
Listening on audio.

O.K. this book takes a patient reader - but, oh my gosh is it worth it! "Jellicoe Road" is this year's winner of the Printz Award for Young Adult Literature. Though the opening two pages are fabulous, for at least the next one hundred pages, I wondered how it could possibly have won this award. It was extremely confusing. But slowly - very slowly - the mysteries and romance and action of the story reveal themselves. For this reason I think many teens, without direction, will give up on it. It takes a sophisticated reader. It would help the reader simply to know that the pages in italics are from a book that one of the main characters is writing, and that the pages in regular font are from the present. Marchetta is clearly the master of the slow, careful reveal. I was literally gasping out loud by the end of the book as everything came together. And talk about loving and investing in characters! Wow! You love them all by the end, flaws and all - Taylor, Jonah, Raffaela, Santangelo, Jessa, Narnie, Tate, Webb, Fitz, and Jude. The writing and imagery are stunning as well. The book is set in Australia; therefore, there are some terms that American readers may struggle with - though most can be figured out from context (ie; singlet).The book is first and foremost about friendship and the love that binds true friends together.

Perhaps I have been reading this in too tired a state to do it justice - the plot is complex and layered and I got to admit I have been confused by this or that detail while finding at the same time the main mystery to be not so mysterious after all. And basically I wanted to really shake all adults in the story. But the teen characters, the friendsship and love story, ah, it was magic. Thanks so much K!

Jellicoe Road, this year's Printz winner, was definitely better than its predecessor, The White Darkness. The first chapter left me awestruck- it was an incredible beginning. However, the next 100 pages are comprised of two stories that swirl around one main character who frankly, is less than likable in the beginning. After the 200 page mark, it is apparent that the structure emulates the main character's confusion- the reader is already beginning to piece together what the main character is beginning to suspect. It is tedious work, but the payoff is worth it- once the story picks up and the characters begin to interact, the story is quite enjoyable. I took off one star for two reasons. One is due to editing. I felt that structurally, the reader could relate to the main story of Jellicoe Road, but the reader never really relates to the secondary story. With as many pages and development allocated by the writer, there should have been more development or in my opinion, less of the secondary story except in the development of the main story (I'm trying to write this without spoiling anything here). There are also some basic mistakes, as noted in other reviews- the ethnicity of one character contradicts itself, there are unexplained lapses in time during scenes, and so on.Finally, this is supposed to be an award-winning book, with an emphasis on literary achievement. While Jellicoe Road does not lack this, I personally see this book as having a rather limited teen audience. I work in a public library, and there is a certain type of teen who would be willing to put in the effort to navigate the complexities of this novel- a novel that is sometimes overly complex and at times somewhat inaccessible. I worked through the first third of the book because it was a Printz winner, and I felt an obligation to finish it. I wonder if teens would do the same- it's not difficult, but it can be a chore. And who wants to make their leisure reading a chore? (This isn't me advocating Twilight for the Printz award, but really, let's take into account the audience of a book, and not just what adults/professionals think).

Jellicoe Road by Melina MarchettaTies together two stories – one of a young lady who feels abandoned by her mother, and one of a group of kids who bond after they are all involved in the same tragic car accident. The reader spends most of the book wondering how these two stories relate to each other, and trying to keep the characters straight. Finally the book resolves itself as the connection between the characters is known, and everybody ends up in a “happily ever after,” despite all the tragedy along the way.Aspects that appeal to teens:Violence, romance, mystery, social groups.Will teens relate:They can relate to abandonment, whether it be physical or emotional.Developmental areas:Family support, but she doesn’t know it’s her family; school boundaries; adult role model, although it’s actually her family; youth programs, if the “warring” factions can be considered as such.Believable or not:Not really – how the school runs itself does not seem realistic, and the wars between the different groups – wouldn’t some adult have put an end to them long ago?How promote book to teens:It’s the Printz award winner for 2009VOYA codes4Q3PMJS

4.5 I loved this book. For the first 100 or so pages, I wasn't exactly sure what was going on, but the writing was so good, it kept me reading. And as the story started to come together, I couldn't put it down.

My experience with this book is similar to other reviewers. It was difficult to process what was going on in the first 200 pages or so, but after that, the book took off like a shot and I could not put it down.

I'm glad that I'm not the only one that was confused by the plot. It reminds me of a Quentin Tarantino movie, where the reader gets thrown into the middle of a plot and is shown different perspectives of the story. It's a confusing ride that I didn't so much enjoy as I was submersed.

At first I thought this would be another boarding school/war games book - but no, it quickly became a fascinating story about family, friends, and connections, all taking place in a tiny Australian town where three groups of teenagers - students at the state-run boarding school just outside town, kids who live in the town, and the Cadets who use the bush outside the town as a training area during school breaks - skirmish every summer. The skirmishing is artificial and thus takes way too much effort to maintain - so the blossoming friendships between the groups take center stage, as does the mysterious connection between a tragic event 20 years ago and main character Taylor, a girl with a big chip on her shoulder. It all comes together gracefully, and with just enough dramatic tension to make it a joy to read. Very well done.

From the prologue:My father took one hundred and thirty-two minutes to die.I counted.It happened on the Jellicoe Road. The prettiest road I’d ever seen, where trees made breezy canopies like a tunnel to Shangri-La. We were going to the ocean, hundreds of miles away, because I wanted to see the ocean and my father said that it was about time the four of us made that journey. I remember asking, “What’s the difference between a trip and a journey?” and my father said, “Narnie, my love, when we get there, you’ll understand,” and that was the last thing he ever said.-------------------------------With a beginning like that, how could you put it down? Well, I did, two times, but the third time…well…wow. Every once in awhile, a book comes along that just hits you in the gut. It hits too close to home, it tears your heart out, it grabs you by the roots of your hair and spins and doesn’t turn loose until well after the last page has been turned. Jellicoe Road did all these things to me and so much more.Taylor Markham has been living at the Jellicoe Road boarding school since her mother abandoned her at the nearby 7-Eleven six years earlier. She doesn’t really know what happened to her father; only that he has been gone for most of her life. Now she’s seventeen has been newly elected to the post of student leader of her dorm and to lead the Underground Community as one of the three boarding schools who battle for territory (among other things) in her small Australian community. The two other gangs are called the Cadets and the Townies. For years these three camps have fought in the “Territory Wars;” wars fought over land, trees, water, and more. Everything is going swimmingly, until Hannah, the closest adult Taylor has to family disappears without a word. Jonah Griggs, the boy Taylor ran away with three years ago and the leader of the Cadets has popped back into her life with smoldering looks and mystifying behavior. And all the young kids of Taylor’s house are now looking to her for everything. Things start falling apart.Understandably Taylor wants to know what’s going on with Hannah. We are given glimpses of a novel that Hannah has been working on, which at first Taylor takes to be fictional but quickly realizes that it might not be so fictional. It provides an all important glimpse of Hannah’s, and Taylor’s, life. As she gets closer and closer to the truth the pieces of the puzzle start to fit together and, well, good luck putting the book down. This is an absorbing story where nothing is quite what it seems and the clues only lead to more questions for Taylor, as she tries to work out the connections between herself, Hannah, her mother and the character’s in Hannah’s book. This is a book about secrets, anguish, pain, love, betrayal, hope, death, life and oh so much more. It’s heartbreaking and beautiful. It’s gorgeous and haunting. It’s going to live with me for a long time, I’m sure. I’m so glad I gave it that third try.Oh and this is important. Jellicoe Road won the Printz Award!

It was difficult to get into, but worth the struggle. My question is what happend to Webb's body? Did I miss that somewhere in the book? If Fitz shot him out of the prayer tree, what did he do with the body?

I was glad that I had some forewarning that the beginning of this book was confusing, because it was. However, it helps that the events in the past are mostly in italics because it makes it easier to go back and review once things start making sense. I don't really recall at what point things started to come together, but once they did I didn't want to put this book down. Excellent choice by the Printz committee.
I ALMOST gave this 5 stars. Very very good.

A little confusing at first, but then that is part of the plot. Having to figure out a world of people, and how they connect is part the journey for Taylor as much as it is the reader. It will engulf you as you start to unravel the mysteries.

This was a great book, and a frustrating book! There are two different sets of characters, one group from the past, and a contemporary one, with no clues as to how they fit together, complicated by the fact that the characters' names are Australian and not obvious (at least to this American) which ones belong to boys, and which ones to girls. You learn right off that there was a car accident that brought five kids together in the past, and that there's a girl named Taylor trying to figure out what they have to do with her now. Fortunately, the plot is strong enough and rewarding enough to be worth it. I got to the end, and just as many other reviewers have said, immediately started again from the beginning.The main character is Taylor, a GIRL, and a student at the boarding school on Jellicoe Road. She's almost an orphan, and lives there year-round, since her mother left her at the age of nine. But Taylor knows there's a lot about her mother's life she doesn't know, and the READER knows it must have something to do with that other timeline. The hard part, the part that takes patience, is reading far enough into the book to find out how.In the meantime, the students of the boarding school are in a complicated wargame they play every year, with the townies and the cadets over territory, that is both fascinating and amusing. Adding to the fun, the intimidating leader of the cadets has a history with Taylor, leader of the students, and the leader of the townies has a history with Taylor's second in command, Raffaela. Oh! And there's a serial killer of kids lurking in the background of the story, too. Listen, just GO with it. Let yourself be confused while tearing through this puzzling yet engrossing book, and then once you have all the pieces, read the beginning again. It's worth it!

I wanted to dislike this book because it felt like another out-of-nowhere Printz pick and my favorite book of the year "Hunger Games" didn't even get an honor. However, I have to admit, it's really really good. I do think it has wide appeal to teen readers, if they chance to pick up a book by an unknown author with an ambiguous title.It's about a girl (Taylor) at a boarding-type school. Every year they have territory wars with the Townies and the Cadets, which is just getting started. Taylor is also struggling with a need to find her mother, who abandoned her when she was 11. That's about all I can say without revealing too much.I didn't give it 5 stars only because the beginning is very confusing. There is no explanation of what is going on, and the italicized memory/story/other monologue exacerbates the problem. However, if you can get through about 50 pages and start to get some idea of what's happening, you'll be hooked.

I give this book 5 stars after page 130. The beginning was not particularly enthralling, but the story definitely evolved towards the end. I can see why some people may not enjoy this book- usually my favourites capture my attention in the first few pages. On The Jellicoe Road was definitely an exception to my rule. The second half of the book excused the slow beginning.The emotion in the book was so raw and touching. Once you understood the relationships and how everyone was linked, you could not help but be affected by the characters' stories. The story went in an opposite direction to what I was expecting by reading the first 100 or so pages. The plot seemed a bit silly and unemotional at the beginning, but it takes a quick change. I don't really want to go into the storyline, because it takes an unpredictable course. When I read this book I had no idea what to expect, and my confusion wasn't really resolved until I was half way into the story. I had many theories as to where the story would go, and most of them were way off. I advise reading this book with no previous knowledge of the plot. If a friend has spilled it to you, well what a shame. Although it was frustrating at the time, I'm glad I was left in the dark. This is by far Melina Marchatta's best work.

Trigger warnings - references to sexual abuse of children.I really liked this, and I managed not to cry til the very end, mostly because I was in public. I want to give it a couple months to settle and then read it again now that I have all the names and things straight.

[Wow! This book was slow to start primarily because it took me a little time to reconcile the two parallel story lines. But once I figured out what was going on, I was hooked. This is an intense book. I'm still not sure if I understand everything.:]Taylor Markham assumes the leadership of her school in their yearly battle for territory with the Townies and the Cadets. Her dealings with these 2 groups bring her back into contact with her past. Through her friend's novel manuscript, Taylor discovers the story of 5 teens on Jellicoe Road 18 years ago. The past meets the present as Taylor finds out who she is.What I thought: This was an intense, intriguing book. I admit that I almost didn't finish it as I was confused for the 1st 30 pages or so. After I sorted out the 2 separate yet connected story lines, I was able to read with more ease. Even now, I'm not sure I understand all that happened in the book.

The twists and turns of this book were predictable to me, but I think it's because I recognized similarities to characters in Finnikin of the Rock and especially Froi of the Exiles, both by Marchetta. I appreciated the depth and artistry of Marchetta's writing, but Jellicoe did not hold life-changing revelation for me, other than to be this densely beautiful piece of art.
Another boarding school book, but not like other boarding school books. Two stories are intertwined and the reader pieces them together as the main characters do.
Kind of confusing at first, but it all comes together in the end. Great book about the struggle of a teenage girl to discover her past. I found it very entertaining.

This book confused me for the first 50 pages or so. I ended up skipping over all the flashbacks because I had no idea what they were of or what they were trying to tell me. However, I soon got into the book and could not put it down. It was so brutally honest, yet sweet and resonating. The story was beautifully and hauntingly written, and I would recommend this to everyone.

when i was younger, i used to write these series of stories about kids with no parents who lived in boarding schools and had dramatic relationships. it was really nice to see someone write it SO MUCH BETTER! couldn't put this book down, totally retract my haterade for it getting the printz over the disreputable history of frankie landeau-banks.

I actually had to take out a notebook and pen to sort out all the characters and what was going on. In the end it all comes together quite nicely. Australian setting had a few terms and words that were unfamiliar to an American, but I believe it earned the Michael Printz medal this year. Funny how that's the second M.P. award winner I've read that is set in a boarding school.

Sort of a slow starter for me - the jumps between the past and present were a little confusing at first, until I caught on to who the characters were. The book definitely finished strong, and I'm anxious to read Marchetta's earlier works, now.
Can't wait...heard great things!

4Q 3P JSTaylor Markham is a senior at a boarding school in Australia. She does not know much about her past and only has a few scattered memories of her early childhood. When she was eleven, her mother abandoned her at a gas station and a woman who lives next to her school picked her up and brought her to the school. Taylor knows that Hannah has some connection to her past, and worries when she disappears without letting Taylor know where she is going or when she will be back. While Taylor worries about her mysterious past and Hannah’s location, she is also supposed to be leading her school in the annual territory wars between the townies and visiting cadets. She is also perplexed by unsettling dreams and a story about five friends who used to go to her school. Can Taylor figure out her past and not let her school down? Or will she cave under the stress?Like many people have said, this book begins slowly, but picks up as the novel progresses and the storylines start coming together. I think that the characters and plot could be appealing to some teens, particularly those who like a challenge and appreciate lots of description. Many of the teens in this book have experienced much loss and have lots of pain to deal with. Reading about these characters could help teens learn to empathize with other people and see the world from another person’s perspective.

I loved this book and would have given it 5 stars except that it didn't fully grab me until about 100 pages in. Initially, I was completely confused, and disinterested in the territory wars, but finally the pieces began falling into place and I raced through the second half. Marchetta has a knack for dialogue and showing intense emotion, and I loved how the dual narratives ultimately came together with healing and hope.

Taylor was abandoned on the Jellico Road when she was 11 years old. She was taken in my Hannah, a caretaker at the Jellico School, a place for wards of the state to go to school until they are 18. Behind the seeming quiet of Jellico School is a feud that goes back before Taylors time there, a secret war going on between the students of Jellico School, the townies and the cadets. Taylor has just been named the leader of the students and it is hear job to regain precious territory from the cadets and townies. Taylor is surprised to find out that her enemy, the leader of the cadets, is the same boy she ran away with when she was 14. When Hannah disappears, Taylor decides to try to unravel the mystery around Hannah, her mother and the hermit. Enemies become unexpected friends when the leaders of the townies and cadets help Taylor in her search.I was super confused when I started reading this book, it really needs a map and a character guide. Because they refer to several people by their last names, I couldn't even keep track of who was a guy and who was a girl. But after about 200 pages I really got into it. I can see why it won the award. It was a beautiful book with some unexpected twists.

I'm still thinking about the annotation. Apparently I started reading this 22 days ago. That's when I read the first two chapters and thought "Nope, can't do this" and shifted it aside to stare at for three weeks. I came back, but with a grumble.It's frustrating and purposely ambiguous for at least 200 pages; the confusing doesn't go away and only lets up enough to give you a few clues. No one ever explains what's going on* and it's set in an unrealistic and unbelievable high school situation ("wars" for territory of trails, buildings, etc between townies, cadets, and the leader of the six houses of a boarding school which in itself seems unlikely and unrealistic) where no one goes to class. Even by the end, you know you need to reread it all to fully get what happened. So, in other words, a perfect candidate for a Printz, no?*Which yes, I get, is the point since Taylor has no damn clue herself but a little background would have made a difference.I didn't like the bits between chapters, even after I figured out what they were and that I shouldn't have been skimming them. Sometimes in a book, these sorts of breaks are nice but here they caused an ugh! and a flipping to see how many pages I had to get through.BUT - and this is an all caps worthy but - by the end, I really liked it.Here's the thing: I was mad at the book but I wanted to keep reading. I couldn't tell you exactly when, but you'll reach a shift where you stop reading just to plow through and start reading because you don't want to put it down. You've just got to be willing to stick with it long enough to make that happen.The massive mystery unwinds slowly but, and you've got to trust me here, it's worth it. There's a large cast of characters to keep track of, but (again after 200 pages) Taylor, Griggs, Raffaela, and Santangelo pull away and you don't feel so lost. Maybe the point I'm trying to make is that while the reading experience is having lots of pieces thrown at you, Marchetta's a good enough writer to hold it all together. A note on stars / recommendation / ages:Firmly between 4-5 stars, if you keep reading. I'd happily reread the second half, no doubtRecommendations are tough. It's worth recommendations but not for all patron and maybe a "stick with it" kind of comment should be included.Also - the Horn Book said 12-14. Roger Sutton, I adore you, but you're crazy. I can't imagine that's where most readers will fall. I'd say 10th on up--not because it's inappropriate for middle school (albeit dark at times in plot and topics) but because it's a text that requires some work and effort to get through. Plus, the main characters (one set, anyway) are for all practical purposes hs seniors.

This fascinating novel deserves the Printz award. I thought it was unnecessarily confusing at the beginning but it all made sense as one read on. The relationships and secrets between a few characters did not seem realistic but it was a gripping read.

Jellicoe Road is the Printz award winner. It takes a long time to understand what this story is all about. It is worth it by the end, and I am glad I read this. Two families have a head on collision on the highway. Their lives then become tangled and intwined for years and several generations. Life isn't easy for any of them and in the end they realize that they have needed eachother all along. The characters realize they are dependant on one another to survive and care about each other. The kids have been spared from the history and details to try to spare them from the agony of hurt and loss. The kids then have a sense of loss and mystery. They try to find out as much as they can on their own. By banding together in their loss and craziness at the house and camp for wayward boys and girls, who don't have a home, on Jellicoe road, they develop friendships that will last a lifetime. The girls are there year round. The boys only come in for summer camp across the river. The kids have had a tradition of territory wars. This was developed as a way to interact and have fun together. The kids create some close relationships that make me wish I could have experienced all the fun. The kids are recovering from horrible experiences but they come together to create a hope and love. What a beautiful story. VOYA quality is a 5. VOYA popularity 3. I don't think many kids will stick through this book long enough to make it to the good part. The kids in this story were able to give eachother some of the development assets that they need to become a healty adult. Most of the family life missing for the kids was given to them by the relationships they formed with each other. The kids were able to go to a place where solid rules were in place. The camp rules were strict and the territory rules were also very strict and thorough. Many times the older kids were expected to care for the younger ones. And although all of the characters had obvious needs that were not getting met. They were able to support eachother through the pain and lacking.

Over all I did really like this book, but the "hook" as they say, didn't appear (at least for me) until page 235, and then I felt I figured out the story by page 243.Strong teen readers will likely keep at this book, but reluctant readers will likely give up.It is truly a wonderful work of literature, and as such and I am pleased that it was the winner of the Printz Award for Young Adult Fiction.

This one's hard ... it was really well written, quite beautiful, strong characters, and good coming-of-age story ... however, it's totally, utterly confusing until you get into Chap 3 - around pg 40!!! The author should have given a clue that the italicized portions (which start the story & intersperse it) are a story one of the characters is writing -- your head is swimming with all these names, and more names, and more names. And on top of that, duelling story lines are going, with the reader just plunked right down in the middle of all this history. All that said, I do recommend it, but it has to be done with explanation, and to someone who really loves to read - will stay with it until it starts making sense and getting good.

This is one of those books that seems to capture all the loneliness and longing of teenage years but in a way that makes you feel for the characters rather than be annoyed by them. It took me a bit to get into the way the storyline flows, but once I figured it out I loved how it was written.

A really phenomenal book - 4.5 stars. Nothing like Finnikin of the Rock, which is a fantasy. Jellicoe Road takes place in our world, in the present day (or close enough to it). Marchetta is a fantastic writer and her books have none of the melodrama that really annoys me about teen books sometimes. She is definitely one of my new favorite authors.

Another great YA read. At first I got really confused between the "past" and "present" and the connections between them. I also had difficulty keeping the 5 characters from the past straight--they all had unisex names and that was confusing. But about half-way through it sucked me in and I really enjoyed it. The mystery of the connections between characters now and in the past and trying to figure it out made it a great read. The romance was really well done.
This is the newest Prinz winner. I liked it, but the confusion of the first fifty pages or so takes some patience to wade through.
Really enthralling, not predictable because of the unique non-linear style. Loved it.

I loved, loved, LOVED this author's first two books, and this one was great, too. Even though it is a young adult book, I think any reader would enjoy it. It tells a story of a teenager who was abandoned by her mother and the trouble she has dealing with her lack of history, while at the same time giving clues about a group a kids who lived in the same town years before that are somehow connected to this girl. It creates a sort of mystery-feeling that helps move the story along, and there are a couple spots that need the push to get past the angsty-teenager pages. I see that in this book as well as the author's previous books that most of the problems for her teenage protagonists, the thing that sends them over the edge and makes all the adults suddenly worry and pay attention, is that they aren't told all the information. The adults around them, trying to "protect them," hide information. The teenagers want the answers, especially this character who doesn't know who she is or where she came from. And when you're at an age where you're trying to define who you are, not knowing is a big deal. Worth running away and getting in trouble over.My only issue with this book is that that tragedies seem a bit over the top, the people a little too damaged, but it's worth over-looking that minor flaw.
I did not want this book to end! I felt like I knew the characters personally and was rooting for each one--even the ones from the past--to find happiness.

Somewhere around halfway through Jellicoe Road Aaron asked me what my book was about and I responded, "...I'm still not really sure, actually."I spent the first 3/4 of the book totally puzzled and the last 1/4 bawling because: the love! the tragedy! the bittersweetness of it all!I was really annoyed for the first 150 pages because I don't like books that are all intentionally convoluted only to pull together at the last minute in an attempt to make you say, "Ah yes! Of course. How clever!" But this one pulled together so beautifully that I forgave it and declared my love for it and am now sorrowing that I must return it to the library. But that structure might make it difficult for readers who don't have the patience to wade through the (very long) confusing bits to get to the wonderful bits at the end. If you can make it, though, it's worth it!
Through the use of more tragedy and conflict than any one person is likely to experience in their lives, this book perfectly captures the intensity of being young and in love.

I can see why this won the Printz award this year. I really really liked this book. I was advised (not by people I know, but by bloggers) to stick with this one, even if the beginning frustrates you beyond all reason. And I was never really frustrated with the book, but I was confused. Especially at the beginning. The book starts out very much like a puzzle and I enjoyed putting the pieces together. There were a few things I had issues with : one, Taylor is hinted at being an unreliable narrator a few times, but it didn't really become an issue in the telling of the story - it wasn't a Catcher in the Rye kind of unreliable narrator sort of situation, but there were a few discrepancies between her story and the stories put forth by other characters. Might have just been me getting my panties in a bunch over nothing. The other thing (and this might be a big thing for some readers) is that I put the pieces together too soon. Before the narrator. In some cases many many pages before the narrator. While I do pride myself on being an expert reader, this bugs me. I feel like I shouldn't know something WAY before the main character does. I should maybe think...could that be? nah, there would have been more hints....not Oh I get it now. Wait....she doesn't? Seriously? So yeah. Other than those two points, I really liked this book. I liked that it was set in Australia, but there wasn't too much crazy slang that threw me off. And I liked the characters and the premise. Intriguing and new. Something different, but yet that dealt with contemporary issues. Two thumbs up.

This book was nothing like I expected, right from page one.First off, the whole concept of the territory wars made it seem like the book should be some sort of post-apocalyptic tale, but then with all the modern-day cultural references (sparingly) sprinkled in, I realized that it was actually a present-day story.The first half of the book was just a tangle of plot and unexplained relationships, both past and present, and it was very disconcerting to not have much of a clue what was going on. The second half really picked up, and the story started to make a bit of sense and finally at the end, the reward was well worth the wait.If I could rate the book in parts, I'd give the first half about three stars, the next quarter four stars, and the end four and a half to five. I guess that with all the confusion at the beginning, I wasn't AS caught up in the story as I could have been so the payoff at the end wasn't a solid five even though I did really enjoy it.I love stories that weave themselves together, making unrelated strands all have a clear place in the tale by the end. Holes is another really enjoyable example.I'd definitely read more of Melina Marchetta. One side note: I did find it interesting that the US version of this book is just called "Jellicoe Road" instead of "On the Jellicoe Road." I wonder why they bothered to change it? It's like changing Northern Lights to The Golden Compass - whyyy? If anyone is going to understand the Northern Lights reference it would be people in this hemisphere, right? Oh well.Read this if you can have some patience for a giant question-mark beginning, knowing that it will all be worth it. :)

This book took some time to get into (although it has one of the most intriguingly engaging first chapters I've ever encountered which made me keep reading.) Once the book started to pick up steam (I found the early chapters on the battle between the Townies, Cadets, and Jellicoe students kind of tedious) I was thoroughly hooked into the story and just started weeping when I reached the end, partly because the last 100 pages are truly beautiful, and partly because I was really sad to see the story end.

A disorienting, multilayered puzzle of a coming-of-age story. The Plot:I'm . . . um . . . not even going to bother. It's too complicated, involving flashbacks, repressed memories, secret journals, a bizarre turf war between private school, military school, and townie kids, a thick coating of slang, and a double-barreled storyline. Marchetta doesn't bother giving a lot of context to what is going on, trusting her readers to have the patience to figure it out themselves. Thus, the first half of the book is darn confusing.However, the SECOND half of the book is impossible to put down. While I feel that the plot relied heavily on coincidences, the characters' ideas and actions so perfectly depicted adolesence -- where a childhood game could concievably be heightened into a overdramatic imitation of adult life, where anything is a good excuse for DRAMA -- that I can understand why the Printz committee chose to give it the big gold sticker this year.

This was really complicated and good. For the first half of the book, I was confused, and really couldn't tell what was going on. The story-within-a-story motif sometimes made it hard for me to keep track of all the characters. Marchetta did a great job of tying it all together, though, and though I figured out the "twists" ahead of time, it was a redemptive, complex and moving story of the main character figuring out her history and family.

I was really confused with everything in the beginning with it going back and forth between what seems like two different hardly related sotries- But it eventually came together and I really liked it. You got to stick with it-it's well worth it! Very beautifully written. It had a lot of heart. Some of it was super sad, and I cried a lot!(What's new-LOL).

Jellicoe Road is a very complex, well written book. The characters are believable and throughout the book I was trying to guess how the characters in the prologue connected with the characters in the story. This kind of drove me a little crazy... wondering and waiting yet the story worked and was very interesting.

I wanted to love it. I liked it A LOT. I think I'm going to like it more on a reread because this is a complicated story of two tales woven together. (I jumped online as soon as I was done and hammered Akilah with questions!) It is worth immersing yourself though; the revelations and rewards are extraordinary.

An amazing read, especially when you get about halfway through. I generally try not to give away spoilers, but I'm going to clue you in on part of a spoiler here, because otherwise the first part of the book would be nearly impossible to follow. There are large sections of italics in the first half of the book. This is another story, written by another character in the book (not saying who, although the reader will figure it out quickly). The first half is a bit disjointed at times, which makes sense because the main character, Taylor Markham, isn't sure where she fits in. She finds herself the reluctant leader of a private school dorm, thrust into planning the annual schemes the school puts up against the Cadets and Townies. Taylor's life is shaken further when Hannah, an adult counselor of sorts who lives on the school grounds, vanishes overnight. Taylor's mother abandoned her near the school when she was 11, and the teen always saw Hannah as a mother figure. She is especially worried because of additional reports of young girls going missing. In addition, it seems like Taylor's closest peers and adults know more about her past than she does -- are are reluctant to give her any details. As I said -- the first half of the book is a bit disjointed, but it's not too bad. Things finally get rolling with the confrontations between the teens at the school, the Townies and the Cadets, and the story finds its stride when the students go on vacation. At that point is when the book becomes purely exhilerating, and the wrap-ups end on many unexpected twists. Some language, but fairly clean overall; good for 8th/9th grade and up.

(Printz Award)It took me quite a few pages to get into this story. At first I was more interested in the side story, which appears in italics, than the main story of Taylor. However, once more of Taylor’s past is revealed and Jonah appears, I was hooked. As more of Taylor is revealed, you begin to understand why so many people try to protect her, even when she is not being nice in return. You cannot help but want to protect her. She just wants to have a mother, to have someone who will love her and not leave her in the middle of nowhere and never look back. As the side story and Taylor’s begin to interconnect, you understand why Taylor was left with Hannah.Teens can relate to Taylor and her school life. So many times high school can feel like a war between the different caste systems. At Taylor’s school, it actually is war. Her need to find Hannah, her reliance on Jonah, who should be her enemy in this war, and her friends are all relatable. In addition, the side story, of how a tragic event can break apart a group of friends and wreak havoc on their future, can also appeal to teens. Friends share so much at this age that most teens are bound to have dealt with situations that solidified friendships for years to come. While Taylor seems one-dimensional at first, she grows into a solid, three-dimensional character by the end. I would have to talk about this book to promote it. Just looking at the cover or reading the jacket flap is not enough to know this book is worth reading. I would tease the two connecting stories and give a hint of Taylor’s emotional conflicts that relate directly to the side story.4Q, 4P, J/S

It took me a bit to get into it but once I listened to CD #1 again, I was hooked. The book tells the story of Taylor Markham, a girl in her last year at the Jellicoe School somewhere in the middle of nowhere, out in the Australian bush. Taylor is prickly and jumpy and angry, and slowly as the story unfolds you learn about her and her background. And as she lets you into her heart, you (= I) learn to like her.At times it's heartwrenching, awful and sad but there's transformation and light at the end of the tunnel (or story). I think I'd like to read it again, and this time actually read the book (though the audio version was very well narrated - can just get a bit hard to keep up with all the different characters. And there are lots.).

I loved this book--the story is excellent and intriguing, the characters are complex and haunting, their relationships are profound. I would have given it 5 stars if it weren't for the very confusing nature of the first 1/4 of the book. I worry that the intended audience (teens) might not power through to get to the beauty and heart of the book. Who am I kidding, I almost thought about putting it down. But then suddenly everything clicks and the story sails through until the powerful ending. I hope not too many readers missed out because of its start.

I was totally confused for the first several chapters of this book, which must have been how Taylor feels until everything starts coming together and she begins to figure out who she is and her story connects with the five kids from that tragic day on the Jellicoe Road. Everything connects just perfectly in the end, even though it's not a happy story, it is just the sort of bittersweet that doesn't leave you feeling depressed.
I listened to the audiobook. It was hard to keep track of where things were heading, but at the end I loved the book.
loved it loads and loads and loads and loads. very poignant
Definitely teen. The first few chapters are confusing, but if you can stick with it, she develops the characters wonderfully and you really feel for Taylor as she tries to uncover her past.

The only thing keeping me from giving this book 5 stars is the first half of it. Although I understand the book now, I just could not get into it and almost gave up on it numerous times. I had to force myself to just sit down and read it, figuring that it won the Printz award for a reason. This book was one of the more confusing ones that I have read in a long time, but I am so glad that I stuck it through.The end of this book makes trudging through the first half worthwhile. Marchetta has done a wonderful job crafting a believable world with unique characters. A mystery at its heart, this story is one that I would recommend to anyone who has the tenacity to see it through to the very end.
A complex, compelling, sweet and tragic story. Yup, I wept through the last few chapters. I read this in one sitting. There are some words a US reader has to translate (singlet, jumper).

this is the sort of story where from the first sentence you are both drawn in and repelled. and, from the first page you know are starting a journey that mirrors the plot.it's organized in a way that reflects the protagonist's sense of time and memories, which leads the reader to be confused - particularly in the beginning. finish the book, it's worth the confusion though! i have to admit, i was lump-in-the-throat crying by the end. it was that good!

Whatever you think about this story, you have to admit that there's nothing simple or obvious about it, unlike other teen fiction offerings today. The story is unusual and complicated, and the two narratives are confusing for a very long time -- distractingly so. In fact, I suspect it will lose a lot of its targeted teen audience because it's "hard".The italicized narrative is, in my opinion, the weak part of the book, and I wish that part of the story had been told in a different way. There are several things about it that bothered me. For instance, the writing is grandiose and overly dramatic to the point of being kind of ridiculous and annoying (Did she really count 132 minutes? Was that before or after Tate crawled over and held their hands? Did they all sit in the same spot for 2 hours and 12 minutes, counting the time? Before Fitz arrived? And then the cars blew up? After 132 + 10 or so minutes? Or was the dad still alive when Fitz dragged him out? Hmmm... ) Also, there is too much omniscient narration for a story told from one person's point of view. Definitely the weak part of the story.However, the part of the book that deals with the day to day life of Taylor and her friends is fascinating and entertaining. I would have enjoyed more tales of the war between the different factions. The Australian setting is neat but negligible -- the story could have taken place in any remote place in any country. I also didn't think it was necessary to tie up every single loose end. Who cares who the serial killer is? Why state what happened to Webb when it's already heavily implied? Why make neat a story that is all about complicated messes?Overall, an enjoyable, fresh read. I think adults who enjoy reading young adult fiction will like this more than teens.

There's a lot going on in this book and at times it feels like a little too much. But overall the book is moving, haunting, wonderfully complex, and definitely different from most other young adult fiction. The first page should grab teens in, but the action unfolds a bit slowly from there. However, especially for teens who like books with a lot of emotion, this one should keep their attention.
Slow start but eventually engaging. I liked the twists and turns, and the abandonment theme.

I read the reviews for this book and could not agree more that the book begins rather confusing but that everything is pieced together in the end.Taylor Markham is a teenager who was abandoned years ago by her mother. When her surrogate mother, Hannah, disappears, Taylor finds Hannah's manuscript about a tragic car accident on Jellicoe Road that happened 20 years ago. What Taylor soon discovers is that the manuscript is the key to unlocking the secret identity of her mother.

I wasn't really looking forward to reading this book. I kind of assume that Printz winners are books that adults think are good but teens won't really like. I still think that might be true of this book. I also wish I hadn't read the jacket, because it made me confused about what was going on for a brief time. However, I also feel like once I realized what was going on, all of the Dickensian coincidences/relationships were very obvious and when they were revealed I wasn't surprised at all. It didn't decrease my enjoyment of the book because the author may not have intended them to be huge shocker moments and I also felt that the story was really meaningful. I don't know that teens would enjoy it because it is kind of heavy and even though the protagonist is a teen, I'm not totally sure a teen would appreciate this book. Worth reading though, without a doubt.
I finished this just before I left for Europe and loved it. I need to go back and think about it some more and will post more on it later.

Like most of the other reviewers, it took me a good 150 pages or so to really start to make sense of how the story was structured and what was going on. And yet, I felt totally okay with that. The story was compelling enough from the opening chapter for me to be willing to sit in that state of tension and confusion as a reader. In fact, it almost seemed appropriate that I should be in that state. I appreciated that the author and setting are Australian as well. :)

I didn't really understand what was happening in the first four chapters of this book, and struggled to catch up the rest of the way. Still, I have to admit, when I finally realized what was going on (that the story a character has been attached to throughout the book is telling the past of her own story), I began to realize how clever and ingenious the book really is. On the surface, there's a lot happening with the regional wars between different factions of a boarding school, and on another layer there's what's happening with a mysterious serial killer and a missing guardian, and on yet another level there's the supposedly fictional narrative that becomes more and more real as the story goes along. Very creative and interesting, and once it finally gets going, hard to put down.

Ok, this book has been on my "to-read" list for years and has sat on my bedside table many times but I just never got around to reading it. I finally got it again and after hearing my sister rave about it, decided to really tackle it.I read it down in Lake Powell and let's just say, I don't think I saw anyone else for hours. Poor Ricky just hung out with the kids in the water while boring Mom read her books. After about page 50 I couldn't put this one down. Did not expect it to turn out the way it did. From the beginning I thought it was going to be a fun loving, camp warfare, pranks and lighthearted comedic young adult. It definitely took a turn away from that. I ended up being a beautiful book about family, friendship, redemption, how the past influences the future, and fears. I thoroughly enjoyed the characters, the story of the Fab Five, and Taylor's search for herself. There were brave moments, funny moments, romantic moments, and sad moments. All in all, a great book. A good book for Young Adults that is well written, finely crafted, and entertaining. Really liked it.*Just a head's up. This does have some foul language.
Fabulous...just as good, if not better than Saving Francesca. Am looking up this author's other works and placing them on hold as well.
I loved listening to this book because the Australian accent helped accentuate the mood. The story was confusing in the beginning as the narration kept shifting.

One brief comment: audiobook is not the way to go with this one, if you're listening on your iPod and keep making stupid mistakes when trying to go back a sentence or two which result in your losing your place altogether. TOO MANY chapters begin essentially the same way!That said, I liked the narrator. Not sure exactly why I liked this one so much, as there were a lot of things I thought inadequately reasoned (like why Hannah didn't just tell Taylor what was going on, or why Taylor didn't recognise a character she'd no reason to forget) and I slightly resented coming to love a character who had deliberately stomped on another character's fingers (with all his considerable body weight *and* heavy boots). Things like that. And the seeming lack of necessity for there to have been QUITE so much tragedy and misfortune in everyone's lives, except to leave things where they needed to be.
