But then sometimes that's the way it goes with a book and reading pleasure is reading pleasure, even if you do have more doubts about the book than you might.

Part mystery, love story, coming of age, this novel is a page turner. Marchetta successfully develops two generations of characters who grab you and become individuals you can relate to. Her insights into teens' thought processes are revealing.Taylor Markham boards at an Australian school. Her mother abandoned her when she was 11 years old. She wants to find her mother but must also deal with the disappearance of her close friend while also seeing to her duties as house leader of her dorm.
i totally did NOT get this book until the end.then i still didn't fully get it. maybe cause it's an australian story? but touching.

I was really into this book as I was reading it and definitely enjoyed it. It's a teen book, so the many strands of the story were not completely developed, but the writing was good and the story is compelling. I will recommend this one.
Beautiful and strange story set in contemporary Australia. The beginning is a little difficult to follow but it is worth pressing forward.

An excellently crafted story, Jellicoe Road jolts the reader through mysteries of the past and present. The unique storyline kept me reading--first, to find out what was going on and finally to find out the happenings of the past. The characters are teenagers with attitude, but they manage to have attitude in a likable way. My one big complaint (and a warning to those who read it) there is one case of teenage sex--very disappointing and unnecessary. The scene isn't explicit, but the fact that it isn't discouraged and no consequences occur is disappointing. As a result, I don't feel comfortable recommending the book to any teenagers, in spite of the great story.

I have never read one of Melina Marchettas books and not love it, of course on the Jellicoe road was no exception. I found the book rather confusing at the beginning because of the two strand narrative used. By the time I was a quarter into the book I was hooked and this technique only had me hooked deeper as I began to understand how the two stories were connected. This book is going to be one that will stay with me long after i finish reading it and though it is a young adult book, I would recommend it for adults as well.

This book won the Printz Award this year, and I've noticed that I tend to love these award winners, except for when I really, really DON'T (White Darkness.) Anyway, On the Jellicoe Road was a very beautiful, intricate story of memory, drama, and friendship told by a compelling young woman living at a boarding school in Australia. The telling of the story included snippets of dreams, a novel being written by one of the characters, and even writing on an old tree at the school. It moved slowly but eventually the world pulled me in and I can tell it is one of those stories whose landscape is going to remain vivid in my mind.

2009 printz honor - Very nice story of Taylor who is left at a 7 -11 by her mother at age 11. Now 17, she has been attending the boarding school on Jellicoe Road. She has dreams and Hannah's story for her to put together Hannah's past and make sense of her dreams. Complicated and thoughtful, it takes a careful read, I should read it again. She does have sex with her boyfriend, but it is more of an aside than a plot point. I should read it again. I think I'll get more out of it. I read it in chunks and not continuously.

In this historical fiction book a group of scouts goes camping on the Hawaiian islands. While camping, an earthquake erupts and causes a massive tidal wave. This is a story of survival. Dylan and Louie must put aside their differences and work together to lead their troop to safety.
Probably would have liked it better without liberal use of the f-word and the scene where having teenage sex seems to "complete" and "liberate" a character

This is really an amazing book. It was recommended to me by my sister Amy, and it was only on this recommendation that I didn't abandon it in the first 100 or so pages. But today I am completely blurry eyed because I stayed up all night unable to put this book down. The story is lovely, heart breaking, surprising and completely satisfying. And if that doesn't tell you anything about the actual story, that is OK. I think that you need to have this book unfold for you to really get the full impact. I know I need time to let it all settle before I start a new book, and I am completely happy for that.
